facts: The Autodromo Nazionale di Monza is a historic race track located near the city of Monza, north of Milan, in Italy.
It is one of the world's oldest automotive racing circuits, built in 1922.
The circuit is known as the Temple of Speed due to its high-speed characteristics and long straights.
Monza features historic banked sections that were used in the past but are now abandoned.
The Tifosi, passionate Italian Ferrari fans, create an incredible atmosphere during the Italian Grand Prix.
The Circuit de Monaco is a street circuit laid out on the city streets of Monte Carlo and La Condamine around the harbour of the Principality of Monaco.
It has been run since 1929 and is considered one of the most important and prestigious automobile races in the world.
The circuit is narrow with many elevation changes and tight corners, making it one of the most demanding tracks in Formula One.
Winning at Monaco is considered one of the greatest achievements in motorsport.
The circuit runs through the streets of Monaco with minimal run-off areas and barriers close to the track.
Silverstone Circuit is built on the site of a World War II Royal Air Force bomber station.
The circuit hosted the first ever Formula One World Championship race in 1950.
It is home to the British Grand Prix and is known for its high-speed corners.
Famous corners include Copse, Maggotts, Becketts, and the high-speed Stowe corner.
The circuit has undergone numerous changes over the years but maintains its fast and flowing character.
Circuit de Spa-Francorchamps is a motor-racing circuit located in Stavelot, Belgium.
It is the longest circuit on the current Formula One calendar at 7.004 kilometers.
The circuit is known for its fast, challenging, and high-speed nature, as well as its unpredictable weather.
The famous Eau Rouge and Raidillon complex is one of the most iconic corners in motorsport.
The circuit features significant elevation changes throughout its layout.
Suzuka Circuit is a motorsport race track located in Ino, Suzuka City, Mie Prefecture, Japan.
It is one of the few circuits in the world to have a figure-eight layout.
The circuit was designed by Dutchman John Hugenholtz and built in 1962.
Famous corners include the 130R, Spoon Curve, and the first corner complex.
Suzuka is considered one of the most challenging and technical circuits in Formula One.
The Autódromo José Carlos Pace is located in the city of São Paulo, Brazil.
It is one of the few Formula One circuits to run counter-clockwise.
The circuit is known for its challenging layout with elevation changes and variable weather conditions.
Named after Brazilian Formula One driver José Carlos Pace, who died in a plane crash in 1977.
The circuit has produced many dramatic and memorable races due to its unique characteristics.
The Melbourne Grand Prix Circuit is a street circuit around Albert Park Lake in Melbourne, Australia.
The circuit uses public roads that are opened to traffic when the race is not being held.
It has been the host of the Australian Grand Prix since 1996.
The circuit is known for its fast and flowing layout with high average speeds.
Features a mix of tight corners, chicanes, and fast straights around the picturesque park setting.
Circuit of the Americas is a Grade 1 FIA-specification race track in Austin, Texas.
It was the first purpose-built Formula One facility in the United States.
The circuit features dramatic elevation changes, with Turn 1 featuring a steep uphill climb.
The layout was designed to incorporate characteristics of several famous circuits from around the world.
COTA has hosted the United States Grand Prix since 2012.
Bahrain International Circuit is located in Sakhir, Bahrain.
It was the first Formula One Grand Prix to be held in the Middle East.
The circuit is set in a desert landscape and features state-of-the-art facilities.
Features long straights and heavy braking zones, making it challenging for both cars and drivers.
The circuit has multiple layout configurations and is equipped with floodlights for night racing.
The Baku City Circuit is a street circuit in Baku, Azerbaijan.
It features one of the longest straights in Formula One at over 2 kilometers.
The circuit passes through the narrow streets of Baku's historic Old City and along the modern waterfront.
Despite being a street circuit, it has some of the highest top speeds in Formula One.
The contrast between the old city walls and modern architecture creates a unique backdrop.
Circuit de Barcelona-Catalunya is located in Montmeló, Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain.
It has been the primary venue for Formula One pre-season testing for many years.
The circuit is known for its technical layout that tests all aspects of a car's performance.
Features a challenging mix of high-speed and low-speed corners.
The circuit has undergone several modifications to improve overtaking opportunities.
The Hungaroring is a motorsport race track in Mogyoród, Hungary.
It was the first Formula One race to be held behind the Iron Curtain in 1986.
The circuit is tight and twisty, often compared to a go-kart track on a larger scale.
Overtaking is notoriously difficult, making qualifying position and strategy crucial.
The circuit is set in a natural amphitheater with good viewing for spectators.
The Autodromo Internazionale Enzo e Dino Ferrari is located in Imola, Italy.
The circuit is named after Enzo Ferrari and his son Alfredo 'Dino' Ferrari.
It features challenging corners including Tamburello, Villeneuve, and Variante Alta.
The circuit has a rich history in Formula One, having hosted many dramatic races.
Known for passionate Italian fans, particularly Ferrari supporters.
The Jeddah Corniche Circuit is a street circuit in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.
It is the fastest street circuit in Formula One with average speeds exceeding 250 km/h.
The circuit runs along the Red Sea waterfront with stunning views.
Features high-speed corners and minimal run-off areas, making it extremely challenging.
The circuit has 27 corners, making it one of the most complex layouts on the calendar.
Marina Bay Street Circuit is a street circuit in Marina Bay, Singapore.
It was the first night race in Formula One history, held under floodlights.
The circuit is known for its bumpy surface and tight, twisting layout.
Features a stunning backdrop of Singapore's modern skyline and Marina Bay Sands.
The heat and humidity make it one of the most physically demanding races for drivers.
Miami International Autodrome is a purpose-built circuit around Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida.
The circuit made its debut on the Formula One calendar in 2022.
Features a complex of corners and a long straight down the front stretch.
The circuit incorporates the stadium parking lots and access roads.
Known for its party atmosphere and entertainment focus alongside the racing.
The Red Bull Ring is a motorsport race track in Spielberg, Styria, Austria.
It is the shortest lap on the current Formula One calendar.
Set in the scenic Styrian mountains with dramatic elevation changes.
Features a fast, flowing layout with good overtaking opportunities.
The circuit was originally known as the Österreichring and has a long racing history.
Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez is located in Mexico City, Mexico.
It is the highest altitude circuit in Formula One at approximately 2,200 meters above sea level.
The thin air affects engine performance and aerodynamics significantly.
Features the famous Peraltada corner and a unique stadium section.
Named after the Rodriguez brothers, Pedro and Ricardo, both racing drivers who died in racing accidents.
Shanghai International Circuit is located in Shanghai, China.
Features a unique snail-shaped Turn 1 and Turn 2 complex.
The circuit has a long back straight providing good overtaking opportunities.
Known for unpredictable weather conditions that can dramatically affect races.
The circuit was designed by Hermann Tilke and opened in 2004.
The Las Vegas Strip Circuit runs through the heart of Las Vegas, Nevada.
Features the famous Las Vegas Strip as part of its layout.
It is a night race with spectacular neon-lit surroundings.
The circuit includes a long straight along the Strip exceeding 2 kilometers.
Made its debut on the Formula One calendar in 2023.
Circuit Gilles Villeneuve is located on Île Notre-Dame in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.
Named after Canadian Formula One legend Gilles Villeneuve.
The circuit is built on an artificial island in the St. Lawrence River.
Features the famous Wall of Champions which has caught out many top drivers over the years.
Known for its combination of long straights and chicanes that create good racing.
Yas Marina Circuit is located on Yas Island in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.
The race is a twilight event, starting in daylight and finishing under floodlights.
Features the stunning Yas Hotel that straddles the track with an iconic design.
The circuit has a mix of tight technical sections and long straights.
Has often hosted the season-ending race with championship deciders.
Circuit Zandvoort is located in the seaside resort town of Zandvoort, Netherlands.
The circuit returned to the Formula One calendar in 2021 after a long absence.
Features heavily banked corners that were added for the modern Formula One return.
Set in the sand dunes near the North Sea coast.
Known for passionate Dutch fans, particularly supporters of Max Verstappen.
The Hockenheimring is located near the town of Hockenheim in Baden-Württemberg, Germany.
The circuit has a rich Formula One heritage dating back to 1970.
Features a stadium section with large grandstands providing excellent viewing.
The modern layout is significantly shorter than the original long, flat-out circuit through the forests.
Known for its mix of fast straights and technical corners.
Circuit Paul Ricard is located in Le Castellet, near Marseille, France.
The circuit is famous for its distinctive blue and red run-off areas.
Features the long Mistral straight with a heavy braking zone at the end.
Known for its technical layout and hot Mediterranean climate.
The circuit has extensive run-off areas making it one of the safest tracks in Formula One.
Sochi Autodrom is located in the Sochi Olympic Park, Russia.
The circuit was built around the venues used for the 2014 Winter Olympics.
Features a long main straight and tight technical sections.
The circuit is a blend of street circuit and permanent track characteristics.
Hosted the Russian Grand Prix from 2014 until being removed from the calendar.
The Sakhir outer layout is an alternative configuration of the Bahrain International Circuit.
This layout was used for the 2020 Sakhir Grand Prix.
It produces one of the fastest lap times in Formula One history.
Features primarily low-speed corners with long straights.
The outer circuit configuration is significantly different from the standard Bahrain GP layout.
The Jeddah Corniche Circuit is a street circuit in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.
It is the fastest street circuit in Formula One with incredibly high average speeds.
Features blind corners and challenging high-speed sections.
Runs along the Red Sea waterfront creating a stunning backdrop.
The circuit is lit by floodlights allowing for night racing.
